84.title: Maestro
84.author: Caran d'Ache.
notes: Published for the first time after the author's manuscript designed at the end of 19th century.
Preface with title: "Le Premier Roman Graphique", p. 3-7 and "Vie et Oeuvre de Caran d'Ache", 4 p. at end, by Thierry Groensteen.

85.heading: Maestro--Articles About.
85.title: "Caran d'Ache : le Retour du Maestro"
85.author: Thierry Groensteen
85.appears_in: p. 10-15 in 9e Art : les Cahiers du Musée de la Bande Dessinée, no. 7 (Jan. 2002).
notes: Begins: "La découverte d'albums de dessins conservés au département des Arts graphiques du Musée du Louvre nous permet de mieux appréhender le projet révolutionnaire conçu par Caran d'Ache en 1894: celue d'un 'roman dessiné' de plus de 300 pages, sans aucun énoncé verbal. Une narration muette sans précédent dans l'histoire de l'art!"

English summary (from p. 150): "Caran d'Ache, the Return of the Maestro." Following the discovery of several of Caran d'Ache's drawing pads, stored at the Louvre, Thierry Groensteen is able to reveal some interesting new facts about Maestro, a textless 'graphic novel' conceived in 1894 and published by the Museum for the first time in 1999. These notebooks include numerous sketches, some of which relate to unpublished pages, as well as a synopsis revealing the story twist envisioned by the author."

86.title: "Maestro!"
86.author: [No author]
86.series: Lash Lightning) 14 p. in Four Favorites, no. 12

87.title: "Maestro : le Chef'd'Oeuvre Retrouvé de Caran d'Ache" p. 58-59 in 9e art : Les Cahiers du Musée de la Bande Dessinée, no. 4
87.author: [No author]
notes: Begins (quoting Caran d'Ache): "Il est notoire que tous les romans parus depuis J.C. sont bâtis d'un façon uniforme quant à l'aspect extérieur et en plus tous ils sont écrits. Eh bien, moi, j'ai l'idée d'y apporter une innovation que je crois de nature à intésser vivement le public! Et c'est? Mais tout simplement de créer un genre nouveau, le roman dessiné."

English summary (from p. 143): "Maestro: Caran d'Ache's Chef-d'oeuvre Lost and Found. In 1894, Caran d'Ache (1856-1908) conceived a project for a 360 page totally silent 'graphic' novel. He didn't finish the work, and it was never published. About a hundred pages of the manuscript have recently been acquired by the Museum. They permit a reconstruction of the script of this comic which would have been revolutionary for its time."

120.heading: Mafalda--Articles About.
120.title: Los Comics : un Tema para Reflexionar
120.author: Wanda Ramírez.
notes: Partial contents: Cap. 1. "¿Y quién es Mafalda?" p. 15-24 ; cap. 5. Origen de las tiras cómics en la República Domicana. p. 51-55.
After an admiring chapter on Mafalda, the author indicts comics, at least as they function in the Dominican Republic, as tools of dictatorship and neo-colonialism.

121.heading: Mafalda--Books About.
121.title: El Discurso del Poder en Mafalda y Calvin and Hobbes
121.author: by Carmen Darcy Poon.
notes: University of Calgary, Department of French, Italian and Spanish, 2005.

"Resumen: Esta tesina trata de las relaciones de poder entre los padres y los hijos en Mafalda de Joaquín Salvador Lavado y Calvin and Hobbes de Bill Watterson. A menudo la dinámica del poder se inverte cuando los niños toman la posición dominante. Analizo la composición visual de las tiras cómicas y el lenguaje de los personajes para demostrar cómo los caricaturistas/artistas manifestan el discurso del poder. La tesis incorpora aspectos teóricos de Arnheim, Kristeva, Foucault y Bajtín. Se puede considerar las tiras cómicas como novelas visuales en serie. Teniendo en cuenta la definición de la novela proporcionada por Bajtín; hago una comparación entre estas dos tiras con las novelas infantiles Peter Pan y Wendy de J.M. Barrie, y Alicia en el País de Maravillas a Través del Espejo de Lewis Carroll."
About child-parent power relationships in two funny kid series, and a comparison with Peter Pan and Alice and Wonderland.

notes: About an FBI listening device in the home of Paul Castellano, head of the Mafia's Gambino Family.

138.heading: Mafia.
138.title: The Clone Conspiracy
138.author: uncovered, verified and written by Allan Gross ; art by Mark Wheatley, Marc Hempel and Damon Willis.
notes: "Some of the material in this book originally appeared in issues 1-5 of the comic book series Doctor Cyborg."

Summary: "This action adventure story proves once and for all that the secret of cloning arose from an ancient civilization, passing through the hands of Moses, Jesus, the mysterious man known as Shakespeare and even John F. Kennedy before falling into the possession of a splinter group of the Freemasons. Hidden ciphers lead to a trail of treachery, murder and deceit that infected the superpower governments of the Cold War, corrupted pious religious leaders and spawned a scientific and academic Mafia that jealously guarded our society's most terrible secret."

139.heading: Mafia.
139.title: "The Difficulties of Adventure" p. 24-31 in Insatiable
139.author: Fernando Caretta ; translated by Laura Petrarca (Seattle, WA : Eros Comix, 1998).
notes: Summary: An editor is tired of his reporter's lukewarm stories, and demands something exciting. Jones, the timid reporter, gets a lead on a Mafia boss and heads for Morocco. He is almost killed, then seduced, then kidnapped, then saved by the Foreign Legion and the F.B.I., and exchanged for a K.G.B. spy. The editor doesn't believe him.

141.heading: Mafia.
141.title: "Inside the Mafia Gang!"
141.author: Bob Haney, script ; Ross Andru and Mike Esposito, art
141.appears_in: 18 p. in World's Finest Comics, no. 194 (June 1970).

142.heading: The Mafia.
142.title: "Jack Kirby & Don Rico Discus WWII, the Mafia, Watergate, & Comic Art" p. 51-56 in The Jack Kirby Collector, no. 20
142.author: [No author]
notes: Interview from 1975, reprinted from Barry Alfonso's fanzine Mysticogryfil.

143.heading: Mafia.
143.title: Last of the Independents
143.author: Matt Fraction, Kieron Dwyer.
notes: About bank robbery and the Mafia.

contents.title: "Marilyn, the Kennedy Brothers, and the Mafia"

145.heading: Mafia.
145.title: True Crime. v. 1, G-Men and Gangsters from Slum Gangs to the Mafia
145.author: by Max Allan Collins & George Hagenauer ; illustrated by Paul Lee.

147.heading: Mafia Bosses.
147.title: "13 Old Men Who Run the World"
147.author: Elliot S
147.appears_in: Maggin, script; Dick Dillin, pencils ; Mike Esposito as Phil Zupa, inks. 7 p. in Action Comics, no. 425 (July 1973).
notes: Summary: Jean Loring is defending Dr. Han Selzheim in a case where he is framed by a mafia boss for stealing gold bullion.
Translated to Spanish as "Los 13 Gobernantes Ancianos," in Supermán, no. 999.
Data from Bob Klein, Jon Ingersol, et al. via Grand Comics Database Project.
